reviewText: I went because I loved Pitt and Dominick's Assassination of Jesse James.  Their take on that bit of tradition I felt stripped bare the heroic images to reveal immature young men walking the edges of sanity.  Killing Them Softly did reveal some immature not-so-young men walking the edges of insanity. It also seemed to be comparing Brad Pitt's hit man, who prefers to kill them softly (not close up and personal), with government CEOs and banker "hit men" who wipe out the poor (including the poor ignorant bastards trying to make money off their heist in this film) from a distance.  But the metaphor doesn't quite come off and the violence is overdone for my sensibilities.  On the up side, Brad Pitt is impressively cool and the acting all top-notch.

On paper, Killing Them Softly sounds like a winning proposition.  It's from director Andrew Dominick, who helmed The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford, one of the finest films of the past decade. It features some excellent actors; Brad Pitt, James Gandolfini, Scott McNairy, Ray Liotta, Richard Jenkins, and Vincent Curatola are all fine actors.  In execution however, the film is a mixed bag. It alternates between a slow talky existential gangster movie and a very blunt political satire.  The finished product has some nice standout scenes and dialogue, but it's too slow and too muddled to be considered a success.

The plot centers around a heist of a poker game that sends the local mafia in New Orleans in to an economic tailspin.  This all happens during the run up to the 2008 presidential election of Barack Obama.  Parallels are drawn between the gangsters in the movie and the people on Wall Street and in Washington who perpetrated the housing bubble that lead to the economic crash.  Criminal activity freezes up and money quits moving, similar to the credit shortage attributed to the banking crash.  Just about every scene has talk radio or CSPAN on in the background.

A few individual scenes stand out.  The heist sequence is near perfect.  Gandolfini's scenes, though somewhat superfluous to the overall narrative, are acted with authority.  Gandolfini really is a fine actor, and he pulls of his scenes with gusto.  The drive out for the final hit is quite well done and suspenseful.

The problem is the individual scenes don't really make for a satisfying whole.  I found the narrative rather slow and too deliberately paced, and this is coming from a guy who normally enjoys when a film takes it's time.  The political subtext is not really subtext at all, considering it almost continuously runs in the background of every scene.  It's about as subtle as a kick in the teeth.  Too much of the film can be summed up as aging and depressed gangsters discussing things in bars, cars, and hotel rooms while political talk radio or CSPAN run in the background.

If you're in to gangster movies then this is worth a look.  It's artistically accomplished and frequently quite arresting visually.  It lacks the painterly compositions Richard Deakins accomplished for Jesse James, but it's grit and grime really come through.  Dominick is obviously a talented director, but he give in to some of his own excesses here a bit too much.

For me, no two ways about it: this was bad.

I wanted to like it.  I thought the cast was sharp (Brad Pitt, James Gandolfini, Ray Liotta, Richard Jenkins, Sam Shepard, Vincent Curatola, and a young actor I like named Scoot McNairy), the adaptation of novelist George V. Higgins' book sounded interesting, and the promising good reviews had come in from Cannes and elsewhere.  I was hoping to discount the low grumbling I'd heard from some of the few members of the general public who did make it to the theaters to see it.

Yes, I hoped I was going to like it, and sure enough I felt the beginning of the movie was extremely promising.  I got the feeling it was trying to be all those gritty movies and cable shows one reveres--a latter-day "Sopranos," or a grittier "Goodfellas" or even...dare I say it? A Tarantino-esque venture.

I though maybe, just maybe there might be something here within the hard-to-like characters and the strange cadence of their conversations: not only between the dumb crooks who felt they could rip off other crooks, but also the ones between two other, sharper crooks who were called in to deal with the first guys.  Oh, good, I thought: a wise "talkie" crime film full of clever, realistic street dialogue and occasional shocking cruelty.

And as it began I thought...how clever to set it in an unusual era (2008, during which a politically charged Senator Obama and sitting president George W. Bush trade their versions of the American dream).  How cleverly the words of politicians will serve as a counterpoint to the brutality in the words and deeds of the criminal element of these "business" men.

Yeah...it's just that it didn't accomplish any of this.  At least not that I felt.  It was a dreary (constantly raining) and dismal film absent of anything that could remotely be thought of as snappy, clever dialogue.  There were a couple of really laughably vulgar comments (especially delivered by Gandolfini), but I didn't think those made it under anything close to wittiness.

I didn't read Higgins' original work, but it had to be better laid out than this.  I didn't mind the rootless ugliness of having to do "business" this way, or the disappointing unfairness of having to do repulsive things, or even the poorly thought out pointlessness of the violent trade--I could take those things.  It was that there was nothing sharp or new about this film.

Okay, I get it: this is a visceral world where bad things happen.  College types need not apply.  And I get the whole counterpoint of the election, too: that America is a business.  And I suppose it could be said that the empty "charm" of the politicians was in its own way hideous to the criminal element, too, right?

No...that may be among the things this was trying to say, but it was dull as dishwater and had the subtlety of a hemorrhoid.  By the tired end of this tired movie I was tired of making excuses on its behalf.  Its dialogue was not witty; it just used a lot of crudity and brashness. I'm not a prude...I just believe there's a difference between good dialogue and bad, and vulgarity has its place among many great works.

But this just wandered around, aimless.  It was like watching a bunch of guys argue for about an hour and a half.  There was action, and it came across as shocking (which it should), but it's a poor movie that simply depends on shock value in place of cleverness.  And sometimes it was stupid: why would a seasoned hit man shoot over the roof of his car at a mark who on the other side of his car?  I couldn't think of a worse "advantage."

And the whole thing about America being a con game...there was such a sledge hammer approach to it as a symbol here that it may as well have had bells go off whenever the TV was blaring its message.  "Here I am!" it shouts..."I'm talking here!"  TV's "Family Guy" uses more nuance.

Sorry, guys, I really wanted to like this.  I'm giving it three stars because, gosh, it DOES have this great cast.  I would love to love this film, but no.  I really didn't.  And, to top it all off, there was suddenly this point when it was abruptly...OVER.

However, I probably shouldn't complain: like the grunts used to say about their military chow: "It was awful and there was too little of it."

Maybe that's the one thing for which I should have thanked THEM.

"Killing them softly" is how hit man Brad Pitt likes to go about his business, but the real killing that goes on here is killing the hour and a half of our lives spent watching this film.

The film is essentially a series of one on one dialogues between various cast members - Pitt and James Gandolfino reminisce, Pitt and Richard Jenkins make deals, Ben Mendelsohn and Trevor Long get stoned together, etc. In between there are a few plot points, but these are few and secondary to the dialogue. While this type of word rich cinematography works at times ("My Breakfast with Andre"), it seems badly out of place in an action film about hit men. Used sparingly (the DeNiro Pacino meeting in "Heat") these scenes can add to a film, but used as the main method of communication, they are risky.

The film is not without some redeeming qualities. The acting is superb. Pitt, Gandolfino, Jenkins, Mendelsohn and Long all put in sterling performances. And the photography by Greig Fraser ("Snow White and the Huntsman", "Bright Star") is excellent as are the special effects. And one can get some sense of ironic pleasure watching Ray Liotta take a beating, since we're used to him being on the opposite side of this interaction.

In the end, the fault must be assigned to writer and director Andrew Dominik who fails to disengage from the one on one vignettes. This is only the third film for Dominick, and his last effort was also with Pitt ("The Assassination of Jesse James...") and also suffered from an over abundance of words and an absence of action.

In addition, Dominik's heavy-handed use of clips from the 2008 Presidential campaign do not serve to underscore his message (crime is business) but rather distract from what is otherwise an excellent display of acting.

Bottom line - great acting and photography in search of a good film. If you're interested in acting per se, this film is a great opportunity to see some excellent acting enhanced by gifted photography. But if you're looking for an engaging film, look elsewhere.

Brad Pitt's performance as mob hit man Jackie is getting a lot of attention but he doesn't come into the picture until well into the second act.  He is hired to "resolve" an issue of mob sanctioned poker games being held up.  One game in particular is run by a small time crook named Markie (Ray Liotta).  In reality, he hired a couple of low-lifes to rob his own game.  Then, years later began to brag about it.  Not smart.  Another set of dimwit crooks (Scoot McNairy and Ben Medelsohn) are persuaded by another (Vincent Curatola) to knock off the game again.  They figure poor old Markie would be fingered, assuming he would be dumb enough to pull the same stunt twice.

Director/writer Andrew Dominik is no stranger to long-winded scenes (check out the superior "The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford" also starring Pitt) but here, it just didn't seem natural.  Certainly Dominik has Scorsese and Tarantino as influences for staging long dialog-heavy scenes between gangsters, not to mention a heavy dose of stylized violence.  The initial hold up scene is pretty tense and very well done.

Later in the film, James Gandolfini shows up as a secondary hit man to help Jackie.  He's ugly, heavy, profane and drunk throughout his scenes.  Gandolfini does a fine job with the role, but it is clearly not essential to the story.  I didn't get it.  Richard Jenkins is the middle manager contact for Jackie and some of the conversations between him and Pitt's character are certainly worthwhile.

Violence?  You bet.  But that is to be expected going in and there are only a couple that might get some people uncomfortable.  The movie isn't terrible but it isn't great either.  The whole bit with Gandolfini's character got me off track somehow.

"Killing Them Softly" (2012 release; 100 min.) reunites writer/director Andrew Dominik with Brad Pitt (following 2007's "The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford"). The movie brings the story of how some small-time thieves hold up a poker game organized for the mob by Markie (played by Ray Liotta). The mob brings in Jackie (played by Brad Pitt) to find out who did the hold-up and to "clean things up, and so Jackie goes about his business. To tell you more of the plot would ruin your viewing experience, you'll just have to see for yourself how it all plays out.

Several comments: when all is said and done, the substantive plot is surprisingly meager, and in that sense there is no suspense whatsoever in how things will turn out. Instead the movie focuses on conversations between the various characters in the movie, which works great. If you've seen the trailer for this movie, you are aware already that there are several violent scenes in the movie, but for the most part they are brought in a very stylish manner (at one point one of the main characters is gunned down and the whole scene, shown in slow motion and set to the 1960s Ketty Lester hit "Love Letters", feels like an orchestrated ballet scene. That said, there is another scene in which Markie is beaten up that is over-the-top violent, so viewer beware. Despite the 1980s feeling to many scenes in the movies (check out many of the cars used by the main characters), the movie is set very specifically in the Fall of 2008, as we see a number of clips featuring Bush and Obama, commenting on the then just exploding financial crisis, which is in marked contrast (or perhaps not?) to the violence occurring in the movie.

But most of all this movie is about incredible acting performances. Let's start off with Brad Pitt, who is masterful as Jackie, with a physical presence in his role that belies his age (Pitt is nearing 50, if you can believe it). Several other side roles are brought quite nicely as well, certainly Ray Liotta as Markie, but also Ben Mendelsohn as one of the poker game robbers who turns out to be a complete junkie living fix to fix. But the real scene-stealer for me was James Gandolfini as Mickey, a one-time associate of Jackie who gets called in by Jackie to provide some assistance but instead it turns out has become a drunk unable to do the job. While Gandolfini has brought this type of "bad" character before, he nevertheless once again does it with a fervor that remains compelling to watch. Bottom line, I enjoyed this movie from start to finish and couldn't believe when the light came on in the theatre tonight how quickly the movie had come and gone. Highly recommended!

I am happy that Killing Them Softly is a vehicle that finally...finally...sees Brad Pitt in a starring role, which is so rare because he has only been in Happy Feet 2, Moneyball, The Tree of Life, Megamind, Inglorious Basterds and The Curious Life of Ben Buttons in just the last couple of years. I'm happy that he will finally have some more cash in his pocket to help feed his wifey, Angelina Jolley. With Xmas coming up, I know how hard it can be for high-earning, Hollywood actors to still feed their wifeys...so I'm happy for his career boost!

Killing Them Softly is, first of all, a totally original work, as demonstrated by the fact that the director like totally s/to/l/e the story from the 1974 George 5 Higgins novella. In this highly original movie, Pitt performs the role of a professional enforcer (read: hitman, but not like Bret the Hitman Hart) by the name of Jackie Coogan. I was originally confused at the naming of the character because Jackie is obviously a name reserved exclusively for the skirts, and Pitt may be a little bit foppish, but he is definitely no dame. Anyhoo, the Pittster as Jackie (girl name) Coogan investigates a heist--which I think is a highfalutin way of saying "robbery"--that happens to happen while a mob-guarded poker game of high stakes is underway! Whew! Just writing that brief summary gave me the runs because it was so action-packed.

Even though this movie is a great example of a modern-day thriller with a bit of a crime caper thrown in, there were parts that just left me cold and ungratified. For instance, during the mob-enforced poker game, because the mob is Italian, all the poker players are seen gorging themselves on Olive Garden takeout food! I never felt so offended in my life at a blatant case of ethnic stereotyping in the movies! Porca miseria, I say, porca miseria! Mama mia...

Another portion of the movie that still sits funny in the pit of my stomach is--again, keep in mind that the plot revolves around the Italian mob--a scene when Pitt and James Gandolfini (played by Will Sa/s/s/o) pose as construction workers to further their investigation. Even though they are supposed to be undercover, they start catcalling and whistling as pretty girls whenever they walk by them!! That is heinous stereotyping of swarthy, Italian-American construction workers and what their behavior may or may not be when pretty girls sashay past them with arched backs! Porca miseria, I say, porca miseria!

"Killing Them Softly" is kind of like if Larry (Michael Pitt) and Tommy (Michael Stuhlbarg) had an entire movie to have entertaining conversations and screw up the entire time instead of being killed off in the opening scene of "Seven Psychopaths." Russell's little dog operation is very similar to the one Billy (Sam Rockwell) and Hans (Christopher Walken) are also a part of in "Seven Psychopaths." The opening credits of "Killing Them Softly" are unique yet extremely irritating. They cut back and forth between Frankie walking down a tunnel as Obama speaks and a black background with white text for the credits. The transition starts off slow at first, but becomes more and more frequent. It puts you on edge and maybe that's the point.

The entire film revolves around really bizarre conversations. Think really off the wall type conversations not unlike those found in "Seven Psychopaths" or the more sex driven conversations between Mads Mikkelsen and Kim Bodnia in Nicholas Winding Refn's "Pusher." Every time two people are in a car, you should pay close attention because it's almost always entertaining. The humor is very dark and covers everything from sex to dish gloves to the economy and everything in between.

One of the best examples of the humor in the film lies within the meaning of the title of the film. Jackie is having this conversation with the driver (Richard Jenkins) and Jackie asks him if he's ever killed anyone before saying some people get very "touchy feely" whenever they're about to die. Jackie then turns to the driver and says, "They cry, they plead, they beg, they piss themselves, they cry for their mothers. It gets embarrassing. I like to kill 'em softly. From a distance."

There are some really fantastic camera techniques utilized in the film. When Jackie is first introduced, he gets out of his car and walks onto a construction site. The camera starts at his feet and slowly pans up to the back of his head as he walks. The camera is propped on the car door as Jackie gets in and out of the car in a scene near the end of the film. One of the most uniquely edited scenes is when Russell is talking to Frankie. After shooting up and being awake for a week straight, Russell begins going in and out of consciousness while he's talking and smoking a cigarette. What you see on screen is almost like the light at the end of a dark tunnel or when you squint your eyes in the bright sun.

There is this really incredible beat down in the rain. The combination of the harsh sound effects, the puddles of blood, the angry assailants, and the helpless victim dancing clumsily in the pouring down rain makes you cringe a bit. The scene is the first real taste of violence in the film and it's so sudden that it almost takes your breath away. Slow motion also deserves a mention. Jackie's first kill is done in slow motion and it is just full of downright mayhem and destruction.

You do wish there was a bit more to "Killing Them Softly" though. The ending is just magnificent as is the last speech given by one of the characters. It's some of the best written material to be put to film this year, but it would've been nice to have seen a bit more action and a little less talking. Everyone in the film listens to politics and it doesn't really all come together until that final scene. The biggest setback is that Mickey (James Gandolfini) is kind of pointless in the long run. Jackie and the driver make him useful, but it's done off-screen. In the meantime, Mickey is useless and does nothing but drink himself stupid and screw every hooker in town.

Next to "Lawless," "Killing Them Softly" is the other must-see mob related film you should go out of your way to see this year. You don't expect it to be as funny as it is, but it's also extremely intense. The film is like a lion stalking its prey. It slowly creeps up on you the entire film until it chooses to pounce and show its true colors. "Killing Them Softly" is a volatile piece of crime cinema that is ferocious and violent as hell.

Degenerative, confusing crime drama follows hitman Jackie Cogan (played fairly straight here by Brad Pitt) as he attempts to straighten out the situation surrounding an upper end card game heist that went down in a style similar to a hijacking that occurred years before. But as he gets closer to completing the job, Cogan becomes more of a revisionist philosopher than he does a true, no-nonsense hitman.
Sad to report, KILLING THEM SOFTLY is really too stylish for its own good, with the camera playing tricks upon the audience, and with the actors trying to mess around with different vocal accents and styles of performance that for me didn't land. Post-GOODFELLAS Ray Liotta gets in over his head in this film, and is savagely beaten to a pulp in an unusually disgusting scene that is a bit shocking for a mainstream film. And yet the majority of the movie runs at a snail's pace, trying to offset the lack of action occurring onscreen by presenting low-life characters who attempt to chew the cud and discuss the current economic crisis of 2008 rather than trying to live meaningful lives. At a mere 97 minutes in length, the word around the Hollywood campfire is that director Andrew Dominick initially prepared a longer cut of the movie that ran in excess of two and a half hours, and might have made more sense than this cramped, unusually empty-headed version that we have here. Although one would be stretching it a bit to refer to Brad Pitt as a technical actor, this role gives him a chance to act tough but really doesn't give him as much to do as you might at first think. In any case, the wonderful (and now unfortunately deceased) James Gandolfini gives what is perhaps the picture's best performance, playing an unconscionably sleazy parolee who is supposed to help Pitt's character get things done (but who only wants to booze it up and visit with the ladies instead). Overall, the picture is too post-modern and too "cool" for its own good--I'd rather be entertained rather than get 'clevered' to death, but clever and subdued is what this movie is really all about.
A project handled by the Weinstein brothers, this movie deserves its R rating 100%, containing some brutal violence, several cold-blooded killings, and some rather ear drubbing (and filthy) dialogue that no other pre-requisite gangster movie can quite prepare you for. And to add insult to injury, there is the typical preachiness involved in the movie's last scene, a race-baiting effort to shame Thomas Jefferson through revisionist lies and to attack our nation for being more "business" than actual country. Some in the audience will undoubtedly cheer on this moment, but I personally found it offensive and (narratively speaking) unnecessary. This one was made by a filmmaker who thinks he understands what it means to make gangster cinema but really only has an academic climatician's sense of what is out there in the atmosphere. It takes more than rain and bloodshed to make a good neo-noir folks. The picture and sound on my DVD were fine, actually quite good overall, but this is not the kind of movie that I can recommend at all. And it does make me a bit mournful in a way, as I was hoping for a better treatment of the source novel by George V. Higgins. In any case, this failed effort won't stop me from watching THE FRIENDS OF EDDIE COYLE again, a much stronger picture made in a more sensible era. F+

I cannot wait for this to be 'rediscovered' in a few years; Killing Them Softly is a classic example of a film being undone by its own marketing -- the ads promised a shotgun-happy Brad Pitt taking out mob bad guys and cracking jokes, but the movie is a sad, slow-burn, dialogue driven, tragic black comedy.  The audience that would love this film hasn't seen it yet, and the audience that would hate it were the folks walking out of the theater all around me.  It takes its sweet time to savor every painful irony, and loves the bitter with the sweet.  Killing Them Softly is one of the great crime films, better even than many of my loved 70's classics, and I return to it at least once every few months.

I love the look of this film and I love the performances.  If you love James Gandolfini, he gets about 10 solid minutes and he's fascinating to watch.  The problem is that this is a crime/gangster genre film but it tries to be a message film.  It tries to say something important about the United States or the economy or whatever.  The problem is that it doesn't do a very good job of it.  It intersperses the movie with real-life audio/video clips from the 2008 financial crisis.  And it does this in a very ham-fisted obvious way - by lingering too long on presidential speeches.  It slows the pacing down and it never lets the viewer forget that this is supposed to be an important film.  The worst thing is that the presidential speeches almost seem to have been added as an afterthought, during the editing process.  As a crime genre film, it's okay.  You see men discussing who should die next for political/business reasons.  The Sopranos also did this well.  Brad Pitt is pretty good as the cynical hitman with a clear-eyed view of what America is today.  But the movie has pacing issues.  If you want to see a cynical in-depth treatment of the financial crisis (which is also riveting and entertaining) then I suggest checking out "The Big Short".

The financial markets are dying.  The robbery is a ironic or even sarcastic remark of the times.

I like it -- but I'm not sure I like liking it.  It's a dark, dark comedy, and it's very well made and splendidly performed.  The basics of the plot follow closely its source -- a novel by George V. Higgins -- but the director, Andrew Dominick, contextualizes the action against the financial meltdown of 2008 and the Presidential election of that same year.  The result is that there's a constant discourse going on about money among the little grifters who rob a mob-backed poker game and the enforcers who seek to make them pay a price, while in the background we constantly hear news reports about the extreme measures that the Federal Reserve is having to take to prop up the financial system and speeches by McCain and Obama that reference a larger hope of a "united" America.  The movie isn't an allegory, though -- rather, it deploys ironic counterpointing of the small-time criminal endeavors in the foreground and the evidence of larger-scale malfeasance in the background, and the two come together in the final scene when Jackie Cogan (Brad Pitt), who has kept up his end of the deal as an "enforcer," has a conversation about what he's owed even as Obama's victory speech is on television in the bar where he is being paid off.  Cogan's final speech -- a comment on Obama's speech and on his own situation -- is wonderfully put over by Brad Pitt.

None of the characters in the movie is remotely likeable, but the two saps who do the robbery that initiates the action (played by Scoot McNairy and Ben Mendelsohn) are so pathetic that you almost feel sorry for them.  Pitt's Jackie is a business-like enforcer, who likes things done with minimum unpleasantness, and from a distance, if possible.  Richard Jenkins is Driver, the liaison between Jackie and the bosses who want the robbers dealt with.  The writing throughout is of very high quality, though those queasy with profanity, sexism, and homophobia should probably steer clear.  James Gandolfini almost steals the show as an alcoholic over-the-hill hit-man hired by Cogan so that he (Cogan) can keep a decent distance from some of the mess.  The scene in which Pitt realizes that Gandolfini's character isn't going to be up to the job is a highlight of the movie.

Dominick also paces the violence in the movie very shrewdly -- the worst of it comes early and is non-lethal.  That means that later in the movie we're mostly savoring interactions between characters, some of whom are trying to avoid the worst consequences of what they have done and others who are trying to bring these consequences about.  The distinctiveness of the characters, the smartness of the writing, and the ironic counterpointing with the financial meltdown keep us hooked.  The pacing is perfect, the plotting is tight (under 100 minutes!), and there isn't a weak link in the cast. Ray Liotta has a cameo and Sam Shepard a mini-cameo.  Brad Pitt, who has become a very versatile actor, gives a sterling performance here, and Gandolfini and Jenkins are splendid too.  Just be aware -- the only uplift here, Obama's rhetoric notwithstanding, is aesthetic.

Killing Them Softly is a neo-noir crime film based on the 1974 novel Cogan's Trade by George V. Higgins.

In the past, Markie Trattman, the proprietor of a criminal poker ring operating in an unspecified New Orleans neighborhood, decides to orchestrate an inside job by paying two men to rob his poker room. He holds up under questioning by the hit-man Dillon, although he later openly admits his involvement to various criminal figures; he suffers no retaliation. Amidst the American financial crisis, a man named Johnny "Squirrel" Amato plans to rob Markie's next poker game, anticipating the mafia will blame Markie for the heist. He enlists Frankie, a nave, former business associate with a boy's voice, and Russell, an unstable heroin addict who is stealing purebred dogs for money, to perform the robbery. Upon completing the crime, Russell travels to Florida to sell the purebred dogs. Driver, an emissary for the mafia, converses with a hit-man named Jackie Cogan. Although Jackie understands Markie was uninvolved in the aforementioned heist, he believes Markie should be murdered in order to restore the mobsters' confidence in the local gambling scene.

The dialogue is sharp and so are the performances. Andrew Dominik directed this neo-noir in a low-key comic style that's alternately gritty and fancy as he mixes conventional mobster mayhem with an unconventional take on gangsters caught up in the Great Recession. And with Brad Pitt as his ideologically enraged male muse hit-man, as if wandering in from Occupy Wall Street. Despite the fact that it is less satisfying than either The Sopranos or Goodfellas,it still manages to entertain the viewer as it is stylish, profane, intelligent, and eminently diverting.

Killing Them Softly starts out on the right foot, with a daring heist and a bunch of wiseguys left reeling. After a big mafia card game is robbed, the wiseguys want answers and turn to a man named Jackie (Brad Pitt), a problem solver who works under the radar to get the right answers to the right people. Almost as soon as the heist and fallout from it are over, the film goes from an Action Thriller to a painfully slow Drama. Killing Them Softly had all the makings of a great mob movie, the story, an intriguing leading character, and three guys who were in the Sopranos. The beginning was amazing and the ending was pretty good too, but for the hour and a half in the middle, nothing happens, and It was infuriating! We all know what a great actor Brad Pitt can be, especially in this type of role, but his talent is just completely wasted by a Writer who had a beginning, an ending, and no idea in between. Aside from Pitt, the rest of the cast only has brief appearance here and there, except for Scoot McNairy, who you may remember from the awful Science Fiction film, Monster. Since then he's turning up everywhere and I couldn't imagine why, until I saw him here. McNairy plays a good kid, who is caught in the middle, and just wants to survive. He goes through a range of emotions and from side to side as if he were a veteran well beyond his years. What a thrill it must have been for a young actor starting out to show up on the set and be surrounded by the likes of Brad Pitt, James Gandolfini, and Ray Liotta! Killing Them Softly
  This is a movie with something for nobody.  We are given some excellent acting by famous people to no good purpose.  Brad Pitt stars in and produced this gritty crime drama.  Pitt plays a mob connected hit man, as does James Gandolfini (The Sopranos) and Ray Liotta another mobster.  All three turn in their best games as we should expect from such fine actors.  But the script by director Andrew Dominik leaves us with no body to cheer for.
 Writer/director Andrew Dominik teamed up with Brad Pitt in The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford.  We might expect a film with such a long name to fail to catch fire with the viewers and so it was.  The Assassination was a critical success with kudos to many of the actors but lost loads loot for the backers.  Killing Them Softly may squeeze out a profit.  Producer Brad Pitt allowed a budget of only $15 million and it has already brought in $25.5 million.  Huzzah for Hollywood as a money machine.
 But it is just too bad for those of us who went to see this dark, nihilistic, unsatisfying peek into the under belly of the lowest sort of criminal life.  The hero of the piece is Brad Pitt, a killer for hire with no redeeming virtues.  He kills people for money and we have no look at the rest of his life to make us have any sympathy for him whatever.  We don't see him helping old ladies across the street or any such acts to humanize him.  He does have the virtue of being relatively efficient, unlike the character played by James Gandolfini.  His character is also a murderer but an inept one at the end of his career.  Ray Liotta plays a gangster so vile and unpleasant that he robs his own illegal card game.  These are men who are hard to emphasize with.  If they are successful, their success is at the expense of other people, if they fail we care so little about them that we are unmoved by their plight.
 There is a clever side light on the entire outlook of the film.  It is set just four years ago during the last months of the Bush administration.  Frequent TV clips show news footage of the time with then President Bush and now President Obama outlining the desperate economic.  This economic situation also impacts the economy of the underworld.  Even the price of a hit has gone down.  Crooks have their own financial problems.  This hook isn't enough to make a successful movie.  All of these jerks can go broke and die, we just don't care.
 This one and a half saw blade film is rated R.  The R is not for violence (which is gross but within current  norms) or naked people but for relentless, consistent language of the worst kind.  We would expect this kind of talk from junkies, crooks and killers but it seems that every other word is something not repeatable in common conversation.
  I think the idea of the film was to emulate such films as the entertaining and clever Snatch, another Brad Pitt vehicle.  If so they missed the mark by a country mile.

I'll start with deconstructing Brad "Hair Flip" Pitt... who cast himself as a hard-as-a-coffin-nail hitman? Yeah, wow. Were the makers trying to show the intricacies of the characters by doing this? Didn't work.

A Lot Of People Were Disappointed With This Film
Because It Was  Represented As Something It Wasn't.
They expected a rollicking gangster action-crime thriller
that would rival some of the many others that have gone down
in movie history as great films.
The deceitful movie company marketing teams knew this all the long,
But felt they had to create some sort of hype to get viewers in the theater seats.
People don't like being toyed with...and they bitterly stayed away from it
after the initial opening week revealed the hoax for what it was!

They most definitely had the cast to make this film happen....
But, the producers, writers, & directors opted to take us
in a little different direction; stylistically & flow-wise...
and I think it really threw some people for a loop when
they saw it...and not in a good way!

When I saw this at the theaters, I saw people
actually walking out 30 and 45 minutes into the film;
cursing the screen & wanting their money back!
I stayed until the credits rolled, but felt that it was missing certain elements
that could've made it a great film.

Since then, I've rented it on  Red Box, just to make sure that I wasn't
making a snap judgment about it, just because
it didn't fit the criteria for what I thought it should've been.
In that viewing, plus in further analysis, since it has been
coming on Showtime quite regularly in the last month or so,
has lead me to reassess my initial opinion.

Now hear me out, before you bind me, and burn me alive in the public square at midnight!

Here's what I say about "Killing Them Softly" now....
It had potential, but fell short of the mark for a truly great piece of work....
HOWEVER, I contend that this film will have more of an influential impact
in this genre, as well as, on how future gangster-action-thriller films are done.
If you take certain scenes for what they brought cinematically, stylistically & content-wise;
like the brutal beat down of Ray Liotta's crooked con man, Markie, by the two thugs
for running the fixed card game gone awry...Man, that is an amazing scene!
It is so real and evocative of what you may hear thuggish-types in big cities like
NYC, Boston, & Philly, etc., call "throwing (someone) a beatin' ".
They beat Liotta's character almost until he's begging for death!
(It's gripping to watch!)

Then, there are the "dirty deeds" scenes where
Brad Pitt's sleek-shrewd-ice-cold mob hit man, Jackie Coogan, does his thing!

That slo-mo bloody death scene that he and Liotta created is part poetry,
part perverse ballet, and part gore-fest!
I find it to be absolutely one of the most original, riveting & compelling death scenes
that I've seen in a film in a long time!
This is what I mean by its impact will be more influential
to filmmakers who take on this genre in the future.
Then, there was the double bloody shotgun / handgun
double-cross killing scenes that Coogan carries out with the
mater-of-fact aloofness, and clinical sensibilities of a surgeon transplanting a vital organ!

There are a few other great scenes in the film that escape me
right now at this late hour, but like I said earlier, their impact and influence
with reverberate in the future.
I predict that "Killing Me Softly" will get its props, 5 to 10 years from now,
when some as-yet-unknown actor and director will create a future masterpiece
in this genre, and reference "Killing Them Softly" as a main influence.
Then people will go back a re-discover it, and say "Ohhh, Okay!"
That my opinion anywayz!
This is an okay film though....not great as it could've been....
but not complete trash either.

A mob card game is robbed, a wise guy is framed, and a hit man is called to deal with it. I admit, on the surface this doesn't seem too appealing. More of the same, right? Maybe not.

Ray Liotta plays "Markie," a mob-connected wise guy who admitted once to robbing his own high stakes poker game. Everybody likes Markie, so no one turned on him, but tensions are a little high. When someone gets the bright idea to rob another of Markie's card games and frame him for it, it seems like the perfect plan. Nobody really trusts Markie anymore, and they'd obviously think he did it again. Unfortunately, loose lips lead to the truth, and hits are ordered.

Enter Brad Pitt as a "seen it all" hit man who likes to "kill `em softly." He doesn't like all the blubbering and pleading that contract victims usually throw out. It's too emotional, too messy. He prefers to hit from an emotional distance and let the mark have at least a moment of peace before he takes a life. Will he really kill Markie just to send a message? Will he turn on the young men who were tricked into robbing the card game? Or will he look into his own dark heart and find a shred of humanity and mercy for his intended victims?

The answers are not all obvious, and they are not all correct, no matter how you guess from the very beginning. This is a classic noir film wrapped in a mob movie. Our lead is an anti-hero, but not in the vein becoming popular with shows like "Breaking Bad" or "Boardwalk Empire," not that those shows are lacking for good acting and writing. This is an old style anti-hero. One who you can tell is not weighed and worried or fighting his inner darkness, but is truly just "doing his job" and has seen so much that his heart may be more stone than human.

Pitt gives a better performance here than we have seen from him since Ocean's 11, but don't mistake that for him playing to that same type. This character is entirely on his own, and no comparison should be drawn to his other roles, as you won't be able to find one. Liotta is vulnerable and sweet, but still slimy enough that you can see why folks would simultaneously forgive and condemn his "Markie." Scoot McNairy and Ben Mendelsohn as the two rookie thieves are so natural that I could not even tell that they were acting during any scene they were in. Here are two guys that should be given a chance to play a different type in an upcoming feature and see what they can do. The late James Gandolfini's character in this movie is literally a throw-away character in that he has no impact on the story, but honestly I cannot fault the inclusion. His character added a richness and depth to the world the movie takes place in, and he is at the same time so repulsive and so pitiable that you just want to smack him and then immediately give him a hug and say you didn't mean it. He's like a giant child who is lashing out from his pain, but just wants you to hold him and tell him it is all going to be OK.

"Killing Them Softly" is not for everyone. It is stylized and odd instead of spelling things out for you. It is slow and calculated and has long stretches of dialogue that seemingly go nowhere. It is full of violence, but no "action." There are really no characters to like, as they are all dirty, selfish people. It plays out against the 2008 American Presidential elections but makes no social commentary on either political party, instead rather waiting until literally the last minute to say anything about the cynical and harsh views its characters have on the country's condition. All these things, however, work in the movie's favor. If you can just go for the ride and give the movie a chance as a "story" rather than a "moral," you will find a return to noir for the modern audience.

The blatant "America stinks" theme permeating this annoying boring film is impossible to miss. The country that has given more blood & treasure to alleviate suffering around the world than all other nations in human history combined once again takes it on the chin by Hollywood leftists. Don't waste your time.

Andrew Dominik seems to have taken a page out of David Mamet's playbook with his 2012 crime noir Killing Them Softly. Instead of the action gangster film that everyone was expecting we get a talky film that explores both the psyche of the modern gangster and the crumbling of the American economy and moral values.

When three inept crooks rob a mob controlled card game things begin to go terribly wrong for them. Frankie(Scoot McNairy), Russell(Ben Mendelsohn) and Squirrel(Vincent Curatola)are small time crooks hoping to hit it big by robbing a mob card game run by Markie Trattman(Ray Liotta). This robbery forces retaliation by the mob in the form of an assassin named Jackie Cogan(Brad Pitt). Cogan perfers killing his victims softly (from a distance) without emotion. The film adds as a counterpoint to this story the fall of the American economy and the bheginning of the Obama administration, Dominik attributes this economic downfall to a collapse in a system based on gambling.

The film does some things quite well: the dialogue is crisp and interesting throughout and the characters are well played and quirky enough to keep the viewer's interest. The biggest problem is that this is not an easy movie to follow and the plot moves along very slowly. If viewed as simply a crime thriller it is not thrilling. Dominik relies on his dialogue to explore the inner workings of the modern gangster and the viewer will learn much by carefully listening. In this way the film follows the style of David Mamet pretty closely. Dominik sees everything based on money. America is not a community as Obama states at the end. It has become a business nothing more or less.

The Blu Ray edition presents the film with very few extras. There are four deleted scenes and a very short making of documentary. This film had great promise but it just doesn't live up to its own hype. Definately worth a rental for the dialogue and character development but on the whole nothing very special.

Well, I see allot of negative reviews left about Killing them Softly" by others. It seems to me that many just couldn't get into this film. You have to really "pay attention". This isn't your typical mindlessly violent action film or mafia movie. It has dialog, and if you wonder for just a moment, you will miss the bigger picture. This is a film/crime drama that just isn't about an order for a hit going out, it also parallels the 2008 economic crash and how the economy not only greatly affected your average blue and white collar workers, but the criminal world a well.
Enter "Jackie" (Brad Pitt), called in to do a favor for a card game that was robbed, and for a second time. The first time they let it slide, but this time the guy running the games "Markie" (played by Ray Liotta) is taking the fall along with the two small time guys who did it and "the Squirrel" who set things in motion. Jackie is faced with some setbacks. After bringing in Mickey (played by the late/great James Gandolfini), who is all but "washed up in alcohol, hookers and a pending jail sentence e), a price is negotiated and the hits are done.
As I was saying, this isn't just a film about the mob, more so it is a film of characters interweaved with the criminal underworld and how the economic crisis affected them and getting things done. The long interludes between Jackie and Mickey are amusing, even if they seem out of place, they drive the plot just as assuredly as did the poker game heist and the 2008 presidential campaign and economic crash that was ever prevalent in the background. Brief, unglorified moments of violence are all that is to be seen here. The true focus is the story and dialog between the characters itself. If you can't handle that and all you want is non-stop, brainless one-liners and grade school dialog, you'd be better off watching a Michael Bay movie

Killing them softly is a very simple story about the repurcussions of a card game heist by a couple of low level street criminals.  There's not a lot of hand-holding or exposition, things are discussed and not clearly explained at times, it's really just a quick snapshot of come cause and effect in the criminal underworld.  It's not about a complex plot or happy endings.

Not a lot of action, but some great performances and overall excellent mood setting and atmosphere.  The guys who pull the heist have nothing and come from nothing, they have nothing to lose and are put up to it by someone who's obviously overreaching, thinking he's out of harm's way.

Anyway - this is more of a mood piece, more cerebral, more of a slow burn.  Brad Pitt is excellent as usual, as is everyone else.  I think the best performance is by Scoot McNairy - who I also enjoyed in Monsters.  He's a really promising young actor, and his character is absolutely heartbreaking.

Killing Them Softly (2012)

Killing Them Softly is a slow-burn crime drama and political metaphor; it is not an action movie. I don't recall any of the filmmakers promising an "action-filled extravaganza" or an "orgy of violence", or any of the other marketing terms one sees on movies these days. Whenever violence happens in a movie like this, it MEANS something, which is the way it should be. Also, I do prefer movies that tell me only what I as a viewer need to know, not films that spoon-feed me every little detail. Whatever's not on the page can be conveyed through the performances of the actors, if they're good enough, and guys like Brad Pitt, James Gandolfini (who is flat out terrific here, R.I.P.), Ray Liotta and Richard Jenkins are DEFINITELY good enough. As for all the political rhetoric, I feel like it was a bit clunky and a little off-putting. I wish Dominik had dialed it down a little bit, because it got repetitive at one point (and not to stereotype, but are a bunch of street-level mob guys and hustlers going to be keeping such close tabs on financial news anyway, to the point where they have their radios tuned to news radio and their TVs tuned to C-SPAN?). Still, I like a film that has some ambition and errs on the side of trying too hard to make the audience think, rather than not at all.

And for the people down below here who complained about having to listen to Obama's speeches, get a life. The point they're making is that the whole system was flawed. They're not lifting Obama up to be a hero; if anything, they're underlining the fact that, after all the flowery speeches and the glowing campaign, it's going to more of the same-old-same-old whoever takes the election. The movies denies whatever pandering "we're-in-this-together" swill Bush and Obama are slinging and sides with Brad Pitt's pragmatic character, who knows that these days, America is every man for himself. It would be a shame to deny yourself a good movie just because of some imagined political affiliation you have that, with each year, has less and less of a distinction anyway.

Of course, if you don't like to actually think, I understand there's a new Transformers movie coming soon, so... enjoy that.

I'm no film elitist. I love many types of films and genres from all over the world. My collection consists of films from "The White Ribbon" to "Harold and Kumar." I take a film for what it intends to be, not what I want it to be or thought it should be. "Killing Them Softly" is a brilliant film, easily one of the best films I've seen in years. Like many have already pointed out it's a parable, and is almost an anti-gangster picture. The dialogue, acting and direction is executed perfectly. The politics might be a little heavy handed at times, and the film might be a tad over-stylized in parts, but it's far better than 99.9% of the pictures released each year that purposefully cater to the average movie goer. There is nothing wrong with being an average movie goer, but I believe many people were a bit misled into thinking this film was an action gangster pic ala "Gangster Squad." But instead of brainless action sequences and a forced romance they received something much deeper, and to their dismay it seems. There is a lot dialogue and little action, but what's there is effective and meticulously crafted. The ending doesn't tie every thing together perfectly with a little ribbon on top, but rather asks questions and makes valid points on our government and capitalist culture. Try and find another film like it out there. Too bad the average movie goer tends to not think outside the box as evidence of all the negativity this great film has gathered. Brad Pitt plays Jackie Cogan, a contract killer hired to set things right when not-so-smart robbers took money from a mobster-run poker game. Based on a book "Cogan's Trade" by George V. Higgins, original writer of Peter Yates-directed "The Friends of Eddie Coyle," "Killing Them Softly" has great 1970-ish visual style, and features solid performances from the impressive cast including Vincent Curatola, James Gandolfini, Richard Jenkins, Ray Liotta, Scoot McNairy, Ben Mendelsohn and Sam Shepard.

For all its technical excellence, however, the film seems caught up in details too much, forgetting that not all audiences would share the same interest as the director. Andrew Dominik, known for "The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford," often lets the dialogue go on and on. Some would love the film for its long conversations - especially those between Brad Pitt and James Gandolfini's characters, while others would hate it for the philosophizing.

The bad economy affects even mobsters. One of the most interesting aspects of "Killing Them Softly" is something economic and political, best represented by a few lines of the embittered killer Jackie Cogan in the final bar scene. Again, while some would find this aspect of the film fascinating, others think it muddled and unfocused, or worse, pretentious.

Even if it were content to be a gritty tough-guy crime thriller, "Killing Them Softly" would still be a bit much. There's one too many slow motion close-up of a pistol's firing pin and corny drug-trip lens flashes to signify that characters are getting high. A couple scenes with James Gandolfini as an alcoholic hit man that should have crackled drag on like improv exercises. Characters take heroin while the Velvet Underground's "Heroin" plays on the soundtrack. Still, for the most part the movie delivers the goods. There are tough guys mixing violence with comically obscene chit-chat. There is a crime that couldn't possibly go wrong that of course goes horribly wrong. There is one brilliant heist set-piece that makes the audience sweat on behalf of stick-up men who are in way over their heads. The cinematography revels in the sleaze of a sickly looking, trash-strewn urban cesspool, and you get to say to yourself, "Hey, there's Ray Liotta." There's nothing wrong with being a B movie, and "Killing Them Softly" is maybe a B-.

The problem is that it wants to be more. And the more it specifically wants to be is an unblinking look at the dark side of the American dream. "Killing them Softly" does this by setting the action in 2008 and filling the background with news clips of Bush and Obama campaigning and holding forth on the Wall Street bailouts. There are no similarities between the national events and the ones on screen besides the fact that both involve money and public perception, like much of human life. (If this movie had actually gone down like the 2008 bailouts, the mob would have showered the guys who knocked off their poker game with cash.) Had "Killing them Softly" retained the 1970s setting of the novel it's based on, we would have heard Carter and Ford in the background, prattling on about stagflation, and it would have seemed equally arbitrary. The deeper message ends up a limp, generic: Republicans, Democrats--they're all crooks. As political commentary, this is slightly less incisive than Mark Russell. Then, not content to let its lousy parts exist solely in the background, "Killing Them Softly" closes with a monologue from Brad Pitt's hitman character in which he says in pretty much so many words, America, it's just as corrupt as the events you've witnessed here, dear viewer. And right there, inches away from the finish line, you watch the movie die.

When I watched the trailer for this movie, I took it for a good old-fashioned syndicate crime movie; i.e.: A couple up-and-comers make a mistake, and Pitt comes in and cleans house. That's what the trailer makes us think. But, that's not entirely what the movie is about, and anyone who is expecting an action-packed crime drama will be gravely disappointed. That's the con of the movie - that it doesn't deliver what we see in the trailer. But, if a viewer can keep an open mind, this film is awesome, and it's truly a cinematic triumph.

Simply-put, this film represents recession-era American crime syndicates; how the recession affected the syndicates. Although it's Hollywood, it's still fairly accurate. Is it slow at times? Yes. But, that just makes it more realistic; the criminal underworld isn't as fast-paced as outsiders imagine. It's also brutal, extremely graphic and occasionally hilarious. When Gandolfini's character was introduced, I laughed hysterically for a good three minutes, and that was enough for me to love this movie. It's pure genius.

Was there a political statement? Kinda. But, it adds to the story line. In 2008, America's economy tanked. When the public has less money, the syndicates have less money, and this was very well portrayed in this film. Add to that life crises, stress, burnout, alcoholism, marital problems, drug abuse and other every-day phenomena, and we're given an accurate expression of what it's like to be a wiseguy in what is literally a dead-end job during The Great Recession.

But, like I said, if all you want is a crime-action-shooter, you'll be disappointed, and I'm guessing that's why many people apparently dislike this film.

"Killing Them Softly" was adapted by director Andrew Dominik from the 1974 novel "Cogan's Trade" by George V. Higgins. In an unnamed American city, struggling businessman Johnny "Squirrel" Amato (Vincent Curatola) hires two ex-cons, Frankie (Scoot McNairy) and Russell (Ben Mendelsohn), to knock over an underground poker game. He assumes that Markie Trattman (Ray Liotta), who runs the game, will be blamed, as he has a history of robbing games. After the clumsy robbery comes off, mob boss Dillon brings in Jackie (Brad Pitt), an enforcer from out of town, to kill the culprits and restore order. But Jackie is savvy enough to understand that Markie, though publicly culpable, had nothing to do with the robbery and to figure out who did.

George V. Higgins began writing noir crime novels in the 1970s under a cloud of malaise occasioned by stagflation, Watergate, high crime rates, and a feeling of social decay peculiar to that decade. Andrew Dominik moved the action to 2008, in the midst of a global financial crisis and US presidential election campaigns, to capitalize on the basic economic nature of the story. Frankie and Russell's robbery has upset the underworld economy. One party stole money from another in order to fulfill its plans, leaving the other in crisis, and Jackie just wants to get paid. Though I can understand why Dominik would choose to adapt this novel at this time, it is not as successful as "The Friends of Eddie Coyle" (1973), which was adapted from Higgins' 1970 novel of the same name.

Though the film is visually arresting, it maintains a distance from the characters that prevents the audience from identifying with their emotions. They are simply spectacle. The story is told primarily though a series of conversations -conversations between Frankie and Russell, which are hilarious, between Frankie and Squirrel, between Jackie and his liaison (Richard Jenkins) with Dillon, between Jackie and a washed-up out-of-town hitman Mickey (James Gandolfini). The conversations are mundane and naturalistic, as if Quentin Tarantino had taken a shot of realism. But they are not affecting. There is no way to connect with the characters, a problem that plagued Dominik's earlier film "The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford" (2007) as well.

Without the ability to see anything from the characters' point of view, they have no impact. The socio-political threads that run through the film are heavy-handed, which tends to undermine any attempt at a theme. In Peter Yates' adaptation of "The Friends of Eddie Coyle", the malaise came through without anyone mentioning stagflation or politics. In contrast, Dominik has television and radio commentary on the financial crisis and election campaign running in the background of "Killing Them Softly". If you have to state your ideas repeatedly in order for them to be understood, your film is not working. There is a lot to like in "Killing Them Softly". The cast is great, as is the dark humor, and cinematography by Grieg Fraser is memorable. But its distance results in superficiality.

The DVD (Anchor Bay 2013): Bonus features are 4 deleted scenes and a featurette entitled "The Making of Killing Them Softly" (5 min), which includes interviews with Andrew Dominik, in which he explains the ideas behind the film and talks about the actors, and interviews with the cast. I'm very glad I read a giant lot of bad reviews because I was expecting it to be bad, but surprisingly it wasn't bad at all. Certainly it was slow moving, and the political messages popping up here and there seemed pointless, as if they were trying to come up with something to say to make the less than interesting script more interesting. All it did was annoy me though. I wondered what the point was. However the good news is that there is a lot to like about this film. It's made in a more traditional manner, like the slow moving crime stories of the 70's were made.

The dialogue is interesting sometimes, especially the segments that included James Gandolfini's character. His acting is as always- superb, and though he's talking about every day subjects like the endless hookers he's slept with, the interesting thing is how well he ponders the subject and reflects upon it. In reality his performance is the most memorable thing about this film. Let's be clear though, this is not an action picture, it's more about mood and atmosphere. It's about taking time to get the audience sitting tight with their seatbelts firmly fastened wondering what is going to happen next. It comes off feeling more like reality. Like the way life really is. Bad men who commit murder discussing their every day lives.

Brad Pitt's character is probably the least interesting thing about this movie. He's playing this guy like the kind of emotionless bad guys we've seen a hundred times in movies. The issue is though that he's simply doing it by the numbers, he's playing it rather bluntly and not with any particular conviction. He's just doing a simple acting job. It's a simple roll, played well enough but it's simply not that interesting of a character or that noteworthy of a performance.

Anyway when there is violence it's not dissapointing. it's rude, brash and unforgiving, just as life can often be. My only gripe is that it takes so much time for the plot to thicken that by the time you start to feel like the movie is paying off it simply ends. It felt too short and abrupt. I didn't like the ending or the manner in which Pitt's character get's political on American immorality in politics, then follows that with a simple "Ef you, Pay Me!!"

The movie has some shining moments but the pay off is not all you hope it will be. It left me wanting more. Wanting more to happen, more character development, more insights into the the crimes and the people who committed them. Killing them Softly is a terse and tense adaptation of George V Higgins' novel Coogan's Trade. Brad Pitt gives a highly disciplined performance as a hit man brought in to restore order in the Boston criminal underworld after the power balance has been upset by a couple of kids robbing a protected poker game.

The movie honours Higgins' style of driving the plot forward through electric dialogue. In essence this movie is about a series of business meetings, except the business under discussion is the organisation and execution of crime and murder. The parallels between the unvarnished capitalism of crime and the hollowness of the American dream is skillfully, though perhaps a trifle heavy-handedly, drawn.

It is a brutal portrayal of violence, but with little gratuitous gore, and no sympathetic characters. It has no epic pretensions but is an almost perfect miniaturist masterpiece.

It's true that the storyline isn't very original, however it's execution was fairly flawless. I'm not a big Brad Pitt fan, but I must admit he pulled off the role of hitman/enforcer with more believability than I would have given him credit for.
Ray Liotta's screen time was short but riveting as the hapless fallout.
The rest of the cast was pretty good as well.

Wow. This has to be the third or fourth movie in a row that was completely different than what I anticipated. Then again I'm not sure what I was expecting since I knew very little information going in. Which is making it hard for me to come up with a solid introduction to this review so I'll just jump right into it.

Now if I would try to summarize the plot it would be a spoiler fest because this movie moves at a very fast pace and gives the viewer little to no breathing room (I'll get into that later). A few years ago a man by the name of Markie Trattman (Ray Liotta) decided to pay a couple of guys to rob his own poker game in an attempt to get a little extra money. When questioned (or should I say beaten in his own house) if he was involved, he denied it. Then when the games started back up he admitted it to a different group of guys that weren't there that night. That's where our first three characters come in.

Johnny "Squirrel" Amatto (Vince Curatola) decides to hire two men, Frankie (Scoot McNairy) & Russell (Ben Mendelsohn), to rob Markie's next poker game. The way he sees it all fingers will point directly to Markie since he did it before and everyone involved would get off scot-free. Well he was partially right as Driver (Richard Jenkins) hires a hitman by the name of Jackie Cogan (Brad Pitt) to help take care of the problem. The only difference is Jackie knows Markie wasn't involved because, let's face it, no one is that stupid. However, he still feels that he needs to be taken out to prove a point. So his job is to find out who is responsible and to make them pay.

I'll leave it at that so as not to give the entire thing away, but this is essentially a pure crime film from start to finish. I'm not one to watch mob films, but I found this one to be enjoyable. There was a solid list of interesting characters, there was a strong script, and there was a great cast. That doesn't mean that the movie is without its flaws though. As I mentioned before the film doesn't give you a lot of breathing room so, for me, Killing Them Softly's biggest downfall is its pacing. There's a pretty extensive list of characters (some of which only appear once or twice) so it could be difficult to follow along at first as you jump from scene to scene.

Which brings me to my next point, the character development in this film is atrocious. We know absolutely nothing about these characters other than their names. With Mickey (James Gandolfini) being the only exception, but that's because he never shuts up. I understand that this is normal for movies like this to focus on the here and now and less on the past unless it relates to the overall story, but it makes all the characters feel like empty shells. The only character I felt for was Frankie, but even then it wasn't anything more than pity.

With that said I think the cast more than makes up for the rough patches that can be found here. The way I see it the directors wanted the general audience to believe that Jackie is the main character, but I had a hard time believing that when 1) He doesn't come in until about 25 minutes into the movie and 2) In comparison with the rest of the cast he doesn't seem all that important. His role is essential to the story, but his character isn't (if that makes any sense). Everyone feels kind of balanced which maybe adds to the feeling that something just feels off. With that said, no matter who the main character is supposed to be it's no exaggeration when I say that everyone involved did a phenomenal job. Usually you have that one person who underperforms, but, in my opinion, they all delivered.

Overall Score: 7.5/10 - Killing Them Softly is one of those rare instances where I felt conflicted with how I felt about the overall experience  It's not a bad film, but at the same time I don't feel like it truly went anywhere. As I said before what really kept me watching was how well-rounded the cast was and how well everyone performed. If you were to ask me this won't go down as one of the most beloved films ever created, but I can see it creating a strong cult following. If you're a fan of crime films or you just have an hour and a half to kill I would say give it a shot. It's probably not for your average Joe who likes a crazy amount of CGI and special effects, but I think film lovers will be able to find something worthwhile in the experience.

Like many who have reviewed this film, I am a fan of gangster movies, and I am truly a fan of film makers who understand the genre, yet are unafraid to stretch the limits of viewers' expectations.  I think Andrew Dominik does this with Killing Them Softly.  Most of the negative reviews might have been positive if the viewers had been familiar with Higgins' novel Cogan's Trade.  Higgins' command of dialogue is the highlight of his writing, maybe more important than the story itself.  It translates really well into this script, and if you're a fan of well-written conversation, Killing Them Softly works.  Dominik overlays Higgins' plot with the political scene from 2008, and this really fit.  Like it or not, Dominik and Higgins say, money is at the core of just about everything, whether it be politics or a mob hit.  As good as the book is, and I think it's great, the movie stands on its own as a great gangster story.  All actors are doing wonderful work here, and each scene is a gem.  If you want a movie-going experience that is scene after scene of superb acting from each player with dialogue that snaps, this is it.  Don't bring the kids.  Mom might not like it, either, even if it does have Brad Pitt.  In contrast to the title, Killing Them Softly is a mean story about hard men doing bad things.  Adjust your expectations--you been warned.

Basically a collection of conversations that revolve around economic crisis, the Mob and some foolish hoodlums, `Killing Them Softly' depends a lot on the natural chemistry between the actors to sell its every frame, and the actors don't disappoint.  It has style (thanks to some sharp shots and slick cinematography) and it carries a poignant theme (that has a tendency to oversell itself at times), but this is a complete actors piece, and as an ensemble this is one of the best of the year.

The film opens with a small time hood getting propositioned to rip off a Mob protected card game.  With a failsafe plan (or so he thinks) he steals the money with a loose tongued addict and winds up being hunted by Jackie Cogan, an enforcer hired to take out the problem and restore order to the games.  Cogan is sharp and takes note of the details, setting up all the right moves with his buddy Mickey (Gandolfini in top notch perfection).  As the walls come crashing in, the small time crooks find themselves in a state of panic, and once Cogan sets his sights on them it's all over.

`Killing Them Softly' had the chance to be perfect.  From a purely thematic standpoint, it's pretty impressive.  The point made about the economy and the state of America as a whole (greedy and selfish) is a very important one, but Dominik really needed to pull in the reigns a tad.  The constant vocal overlay that thrusts political viewpoints in our ears like some sort of subconscious manipulation was just too much.  All of that stripped out and the mere conversations (so rich) to fall back on and this film would have been EVERYTHING.  The closing statement, Pitt's words, have so much meaning and carry so much weight and yet they are dampened because of the fact that the film has already lead us to believe those words so many times before.  Take out all the unnecessary news clips and you would have had one of the best films of 2012.

Still, this is a great film and one that should be seen.  Like I said, one of the best ensembles of the year.  Pitt, Gandolfini, Jenkins and McNairy are spot on perfection here, adding so much depth to their characters and taking this film so far.

I almost didn't watch this movie because of the generally poor reviews. Thankfully I ignored them and was able to enjoy a refreshingly new take on the gangster drama. Before I get into the review I should also add that I rarely write reviews for Amazon, but felt obligated because so many people misjudged this movie and gave it a completely erroneous review and rating. Now let's get to it!

First off, I found this movie to be exhilarating. I watched this at home on a small screen, and I was still constantly on edge, tense, with elevated heart rate. The reason for this is because the movie is in my opinion so real. It gives the gritty, down and dirty real world representation of the criminal lifestyle without all the bells and whistles/faux glamor that most Hollywood movies in this genre have. We don't admire these characters, and honestly we shouldn't. They are losers, degenerates, addicts, gamblers, alcoholics, and murderers. We know it, and what's more the characters themselves know it. They aren't "cool" or "likeable". They are real. And that's one thing that makes this movie so good.

Second, the exchange of words between characters is astoundingly great and often filled with hilarious vulgarity. If you got offended, you HAVE to know going into this movie that people talk this way, especially characters of this caliber. To be bothered by things that were said in this film is to not go into it with an open mind. And in no way was the dialogue boring as many reviewers have said. I felt that it was constantly enriching the story, creating fuller characters, and backing the major themes of this film along the way, all while doing so in a real way and with accurate representation of how people talk in the real world.

This brings me to my last major point of this review. Anyone who saw this movie as having a political agenda clearly missed the entire point of all the sound bites and video clips dispersed throughout. If you pay attention you will notice that all of those clips are united under one major theme: money. This film boils down to that one thing. It's what everyone wants and strives for in Killing Them Softly. From the opening shot to the cut to black, everyone just wants to get paid. Some do, some don't, and some pay for it with their lives. If you don't see that this movie is really about American greed and the idea of trying to make a quick buck, whether it be from selling drugs, playing cards, robbing people or even murdering them, than you completely missed it. This movie is about everyone feeling the financial pinch of our floundering economy, even those in the criminal world. Please watch this movie, and do it with an open mind. I assure you that you won't be disappointed. I sure wasn't.

Firmly rooted in the recession of 2008, KILLING THEM SOFTLY is far from the action film it was unfortunately promoted as.  In fact, it's main attraction, Brad Pitt, doesn't even enter the picture until about 30 minutes, and isn't a key player until nearer the end.  It's not even a gangster film in the traditional style--the epic rise and fall of some ne'er-do-well.  It's an intensely intimate tale of two criminal idiots who get in over their heads, causing other people to take the fall for their crimes.  And it's about the people who come in and clean up the mess, all because these days, you gotta do what you gotta do to get a buck.

Writer/director Andrew Dominik brings to SOFTLY the same slow-burning intensity he gave to THE ASSASSINATION OF JESSE JAMES BY THE COWARD ROBERT FORD; but, being half that film's length, SOFTLY comes off as far more intense.  One scene in particular, where Ray Liotta's unfortunate Markie takes a beating, is especially difficult to watch; Dominik pulls no punches here in framing the brutality of the situation.  And yet, there's a surprising undertone of humor, centered largely around Richard Jenkins's unnamed character: he's a criminal of the new order, a bureaucratic middleman, and paired up against the more pragmatic Brad Pitt ("Now f***in' pay me"), he's a fish out of water.

This is an actor's film; great turns are had by Sam Shepard, Scoot McNairy, Ben Mendelsohn, James Gandolfini, and especially the afore-mentioned Jenkins and Liotta (cast gloriously against type).  Pitt is the major attraction here, but his performance is so subtle and understated that no doubt many fans will be disappointed.  And yet, Pitt digs under your skin, and in the final scene, when he really cuts loose about the one thing that really matters--money--you sense how everything has been building to this moment.  Because, believe it or not, this is a gangster film about economics.  It's a gangster film about America; but instead of CASINO or SCARFACE or GOODFELLAS, it's about the side of America that we're used to, because to an extent, most of us have been there.  When they talk about films that encapsulate the early 21st century, and the shift in economy and politics, they will reference this film.  Which, perhaps, makes this an important little movie.  Give KILLING THEM SOFTLY a shot; if you have the patience to sit through it, the experience is rewarding, if a little off-putting at times.

Okay.  It's an art film.  And yes, it has too many deep characterizations and convoluted conversations to please the "Scarface" and "Goodfellas" fans. James Gandolfini plays one of the most despicable and pathetic thugs you'll ever see on film, a drunk, womanizing lout ready to be flushed to his doom.  Brad Pitt's Cogan is not a cheerful dude.  But Cogan is cool, practical, and wise to economic reality.  It's a subtle film, but if you've got the right ear and eye for it, you'll enjoy a unique and intelligent piece of cinema.  "Killing Them Softly" speaks to modern American politics better than anything coming out of the big Hollywood studios.  It shows us an economic wasteland where everyone is looking to get paid, and everybody is broke.  Does that sound like a country we all know and love?  If you can't see the merits of this film, you're just looking for escapism.  Go watch some superhero franchise instead.  Leave the real nitty gritty to those of us who can cope with it.

I wanted to like this film. I tried to appreciate this film for what it is rather than what I wanted it to be, but ultimately I was left with disappointment. Before I go any farther, I will issue a general warning that spoilers may lie ahead. If that presents a problem then you probably shouldn't be reading these reviews in the first place.

On the positive side, the cinematography is striking and most scenes are composed beautifully. The film is a visual treat. The dialogue can be clever, if largely pointless and time wasting. The pace is inconsistent but when it works, it works very well. The actors bring a genuine quality to their characters. "Nuanced" is a description that is overused, in my opinion, but it is an apt description for many of the performances on display here.

On the other hand,the single most damning criticism of this film is that it is boring. Really, really boring. As previously mentioned, the inconsistent pacing is part of the problem, along with self indulgent dialogue and pointless plot elements. One case in point is Gandolfini's character, Mickey.

If there is a prime example of what is wrong with this film, it is Mickey. His dialogue seems to last forever as it dwells on pointless detail, going nowhere to advance the plot and, ultimately, his introduction into the story yields nothing more than the mob accountant complaining about misspent money. Andrew Dominik is, after only three films, a truly unique talent and perhaps one of the best directors working today.
