I can see how some people would be turned off by this film, it's an odd and heady mix of politics, mob movie, grit, dirt, and the characters are a mash up of broken down drunks, ex-cons, and druggies who are barely hanging on to an America that's given up on them (or just never knew about them in the first place.) But for all it's weight Killing them Softly never cracks. It's frequently funny (albeit darkly funny) and hits you square in the chest. It's brutal but beautifully so. Brad Pitt, is a performer whose truly come into his own in the last 10 to 15 years and Killing them Softly is the culmination of all of that talent. James Gandolfini is as always wonderful but I think the true standout is Scoot McNairy playing the ex-con drug addict who embodies every American dream gone (way) wrong. Not only does he frequently steal the show from everyone he shares the screen with and not only does he gain sympathy from the audience he completely breaks your heart with his stunning performance. Killing them Softly is a true masterwork from a director who will one day be a legend. This is one you cannot miss.

Andrew Dominik's screenplay and direction of George V. Higgins' novel `Cogan's Trade' may have to search for the right audience because it is a complexly designed and performed piece of cinema.  But for those who are willing to step into a different stratosphere of combining gangland antics and brutality with a strong subtext of commentary on the current status of American political system - a film packed with some top notch performances by a varied set of actors - then spend some time with KILLING THEM SOFTLY. The title comes from the main character professional hitman Jackie Cogan who confides that he likes to carry out his missions without getting to close to the victims so that he doesn't have to hear their whining and pleas and crying etc as he kills them - distance allows him to kill them softly.

We learn that Markie (Ray Liotta) some years back made a lot of money by raiding a gambling game.  Since it worked before, odds are that it will work again now that Markie is out and in the mob controlled gambling scene. Some amateurs (Scoot McNairy and Ben Mendelsohn, both losers on heroin) are hired by Johnny Amato (Vincent Curatola) to stickup a mob protected card game, causing the local criminal economy to collapse. Jackie Cogan (Brad Pitt) is an enforcer for the Mob and is called in by an unnamed driver (Richard Jenkins) who is brokering the deal to track them down and restore order to the local criminal economy. Cogan demands that an assistant Mickey (James Gandolfini) be brought in, but when Mickey arrives in town he is far more interested in prostitutes and staying drunk than doing his job. How the final plan to correct the problem is carried out is the rapid-fire sequence of the last part of the film and to spoil it would be a shame.

In many ways the movie is a recreation of the 2008 financial crisis - each character represents a different contemporary type (e.g., Richard Jenkins is the American government, etc). Under much of the dialogue for the film is the presence of political television shows with Bush and Obama talking, underlining the 2008 financial crisis, and that adds to the veracity of the story.  The actors are excellent, the action is a bit on the gory side, but the seemingly endless and roaming dialogue holds a lot of viewpoints that are salient and make these underbelly jerks credible.  You simply have to be in the mood for this one.  Grady Harp, March 13

That America is about big business and the ruthlessness of big business is highlighted by running parallelsbetween the American election campaign in the background with the voices of George Bush and Obama on TV screens where the economy has been hit by a crash,and the criminal community's economy collapse,because a mob-protected card game hosted by Markie Trattman(Liotta)has been robbed by two dumb hoods hired by small-time crookJohhny Amato, to make some easy money. In this film the criminals talk the talk,we are led by the dialogue into espying what the contrasting action set-pieces will be,figuring out the plot,where they walk the walk. The weaselly ex-con Frankie(Scot McNairy) and his addled side-kick Russell(Mendelsohn) have knocked over the poker game,one to get a better car and more sex,the other to get drugged,you know they are both doomed. Also Markie having previously robbed his own game,suspicion will immediately fall on him again.

A mob fixer hires Jackie Cogan(Pitt) to eliminate the perpetrators of the robbery and restore confidence. Writer-director Dominik has adapted/updated Higgins 70s novel,Cogan's Trade,to show the fissure opened up in the idea of community, whereby organised crime is a microcosm of the whole. Ideals are a faade that masks a system run on individual self-interest and greed. The hold-up with sawn-off shot guns is edgy,unpredictable,the violence of Markie's beating up is hard to watch,these are grimy,scummy people who treat women like dirt and hold life in contempt. Pitt's amiable assassin prefers to "kill them softly",pick his targets off long range,flitting from personal bonhomie to dead-eyed murderous efficiency. Cogan thinks bringing in fellow assassin Mickey(Gandolfini) to share the hits,only for the latter to prove a drunken,sex-addicted liability. The film has some beautifully weighted scenes of dialogue between Cogan and Jenkins,a middle management operative,Cogan and Mickey,with more flamboyant set-pieces, a slow-mo symphony of breaking glass and spurting blood,accompanied by ballads like `Love Letters.'The film is full of a kind of dirty realism,dark shadows,vintage autos prowling through the night,and the slangy zing of foul-mouthed punks who are prey to corporate manoeuvres,which dictate you have to kill someone who wasn't responsible for the heist to restore public trust. Richard Jenkins,Ray Liotta ,Gandolfini all bring class to their roles. Pitt is supreme. His best acting role for years.

KILLING THEM SOFTLY, the riveting crime drama from writer/director Andrew Dominik, evokes memories of Quentin Tarantino's RESERVOIR DOGS, in that it spends a lot of time, particularly before anything significant happens, exploring the personalities of pair of secondary characters; not-too-bright amateur criminals who are about to enter the "big time" with disastrous results.

These two schmucks (Scoot McNairy, Ben Mendelsohn), with the plan of fellow ex-con Vincent Curatola, make the mistake of holding up a Mob card game, run by Ray Liotta.  Curatola figures that, since Liotta had engineered a heist of his game once before, he will be blamed for this robbery also.

Mendelsohn, however,  is not only a drug addict, but he also has a big mouth, and it not long before the Mob (represented by Richard Jenkins) knows the identities of the guys who pulled off the job.  Enforcer Brad Pitt is called in to take care of the three culprits, as well as Liotta, whose "hit" is necessary in the interest of "public relations".

What makes KILLING THEM SOFTLY a unique crime drama, as well as a dark comedy, is that the action is played against the 2008 financial meltdown and Presidential campaign.  Like with the national meltdown, the robbing of the Mob card game has hurt the local crime economy.  For example, when Pitt tells Jenkins that he needs to bring in another hit man (James Gandolfini) to help him with pull off the 3-4 contact killings, the Mob boss' agrees to the price, but then insists, "Have him fly coach".

Gritty dialogue, multi-dimensional characters, and fine performances all around results in this release from Anchor Bay Entertainment being one of the finest, and most realistic crime dramas of the past decade.

A word of caution: The scenes of violence are extremely violent; not for the squeamish.

DVD extras include a "Making of" featurette and four deleted scenes.

This movie has gotten a raw deal.  It is a 5-star movie.  The problem is it's an exceedingly subtle movie.  Read through the mixed to negative reviews and you see one of two things (or both things):  either the person thinks the movie is superficial politica, or they had expectations (because of the gangster genre) and were let down.

Here's the thing.  This movie is a recreation of the 2008 financial crisis.  Every character in the movie represents a different group (like Richard Jenkins is obviously the American government).  When you view the movie with this frame, as a parable, I think it takes on new dimensions.  You're suddenly comparing characters and groups of characters (like the poker players) to their real-life equivalents (the poker players represent the American 1%).  But you're also looking at the interaction between characters and then what that's saying about the interaction between the real-life equivalents.  What do I mean by that?  The final speech.  I won't give it away, but a lot of reviewers and people who have seen the movie say the final speech is cheesy.  Sure.  Except when you view it through the frame of "Brad Pitt's character has a real-life equivalent", the final speech takes on a different dynamic.  It isn't just some speech in a fictional narrative of some movie.  It has a real-world influence, it represents something that's not fiction.  Who does Brad Pitt's character represent?  It's not a "who" rather than a "what".  (Hint:  it's the American Spirit).  The question isn't "is the speech cheesy or not, is it bad or not, is it cool or not?"  The question is:  do you agree that the speech is representative of the 21st Century American Spirit?  If not, why?  If so, why?  If you agree, does the speech make you feel a rush of pride or discomfort?  Then you also have to analyze what it means that it's the avatar for the American Spirit that ends the movie with a surge of emotion.  Is Andrew Dominick saying that despite all the **** from the 2008 crisis, the American Spirit will overcome it and win out?  I think so.

In other words:  imagine taking the 2008 financial crisis and condensing it into a fairy tale wearing gangster clothes.  That's what "Killing Them Softly" is.

Don't expect a fast-moving gangster movie.  Don't expect "The Departed" or "Goodfellas".

Don't short-change the movie and think it's dumber than what it thinks it is.  If it's not smarter than you, it's at least as smart as you.

It's fine if you understand what the movie is doing and still don't like it.  Maybe it really is too slow for you.  Maybe you just don't like these kinds of movies.  It's not a bad movie, though.

Given time, people and critics and scholars will come to appreciate this movie.  I hope you're one of them.

In Killing Them Softly, Brad Pitt stars as Jackie Cogan, a mafia hitman hired to take out the individuals responsible for robbing a poker game.  Mickey (Ray Liotta) runs the game, but already knocked over (robbed) his own game once before, leading to an implication that he did it once again.  Scott McNairy, Ben Mendelsohn, Richard Jenkins, James Gandolfini, and Vincent Curatola also star in supporting roles.

At some point, a typical gangster film or television show will feature a gangster-run card game.  However, it typically ends with some kind of shootout - yet in this particular film, the robbers easily get away with the cash, but are simply too stupid to leave town after the deed.  What does all of this mean for this film?  It means it's a slow moving, realistic plot that has very little entertainment value until the end.  And, even in the end, the audience will easily see how the film is going by the end.

The cast is one of the bright spots of the film.  Brad Pitt does a marvelous job (as usual), while Ray Liotta plays his typical gangster role dating back several years to Goodfellas.  We also see a bit of a Sopranos reunion with James Gandolfini - in a very unusual role - along with Vincent Curatola, and Max Casella, even though none of them have any scenes together.  In the end, it's Scoot McNairy and Ben Mendelsohn who really steal the show in this one.  Their scatterbrained/humorous exchanges are about the only thing stopping you from falling asleep.

Overall, this makes for a tough date night film to sit through - unless you're a gangster enthusiast.  Running at just over 90 minutes, it will feel like 3 hours, but don't mistake this for a bad film because it's not date night worthy.  This film is worthy of achievement, but unfortunately - it's the kiss of death for a date night film.

Writer/director Andrew Dominik proved himself a visual poet when he made The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford in 2007. That film, also starring Brad Pitt, was a masterpiece and I had high hopes for Killing Them Softly. After all, it's based on the novel Cogan's Trade by George V. Higgins who also wrote The Friends of Eddie Coyle, which was adapted into a terrific 1973 film. What could go wrong? Well, critics have mostly been warm to the film but it's been met with scorn by audiences. Is it the masterpiece I expected from Dominik? No. Is it subtle? Most definitely not. But is there much to admire about it? Certainly.

The film opens with Frankie (Scoot McNairy), obviously distressed, walking through a New Orleans-area wasteland while clips of a speech by then-Senator Barack Obama play on the soundtrack. The setting is election year 2008 as the country is experiencing an economic downturn. Frankie and his perpetually sweaty, Australian business associate Russell (Ben Mendelsohn) are low-level thugs recruited by Johnny "Squirrel" Amato (Vincent Curatola) to knock over a card game. Frankie is skittish about the job, pointing out that they'll all be murdered if they do it, until Squirrel reveals the game is run by Markie Trattman (Ray Liotta). Years ago, Markie had orchestrated the robbery of one of his games and gotten away with it. Now it's common knowledge that he was responsible and if another one of his games is knocked over, he'll be suspect and take the fall. Things initially go well for the robbers, but when hitman Jackie Cogan (Pitt) arrives he doesn't believe everything went down exactly as it appears. Political speeches by both George W. Bush and Obama are featured prominently throughout the film, particularly speeches regarding money and the economy.

Killing Them Softly appears to be a straight-forward crime thriller, but has nearly wall-to-wall dialogue and grander ideas than that genre suggests. In inserting these speeches into the film with absolutely zero subtlety, we have Dominik paralleling the collapse of the U.S. economy with the collapse of the economy within the crime world. Killing Them Softly is certainly stylish, but with such a heavy-handed allegory, it seems to be grasping for substance. It doesn't lack substance per se; there's some strong dialogue with great depth, but the film lacks some vague essential element.

Cinematographer Greig Fraser employs a muted color palette that makes New Orleans look like a post-apocalyptic wasteland. It's not as visually intriguing as The Assassination of Jesse James, but the visual prowess adds to the film's effect. During breaks from dialogue, the film does become ultra-violent and it does so in a visually interesting way. There's a scene where a character is brutally beaten and the way Dominik illustrates the brutality makes it hard to stomach. A subsequent murder scene is shown in ultra-slow motion and it's a work of visual panache and artistry. The look and tone established by the photography moves the film along better than the characters and dialogue do.

Every performance here is strong, but none are Oscar-worthy. Pitt's cool, mature performance continues his streak of quality performances in mostly quality films. There is an element of typecasting that works in the film's favor, particularly in regards to Liotta and James Gandolfini as Jackie's troubled hitman friend Mickey, allowing the film to establish the persona of the characters without giving too much back story. Mendelsohn meanwhile nearly steals the show from his more well-known peers as the unreliable junkie Russell.

Like much of the film the dialogue is heavy-handed, but it's very strong, specifically in the closing scene. The final lines spoken by Pitt make Dominik's point loud and clear and the lines themselves are startling and powerful, yet the ending doesn't quite work either. In many ways, Killing Them Softly feels incomplete; like small pieces of a larger masterpiece. The original cut was two and a half hours, while the final cut runs just over 90 minutes. I didn't know this beforehand and I still sensed the film may have been missing crucial scenes. There's a distinct lack of development in terms of plot and character that some of the missing scenes may have restored and the lack of proper build-up makes some scenes that should have had an impact simply hit the wall. Take the Mickey character for example. He arrives and shows more of an interest in prostitutes and booze than the job he came to do, but then his character's gone with a simple explanation. Perhaps his character had some contribution or meaning within the longer cut, but here he seems like filler. His character serves no purpose, except maybe to show that Jackie has empathy for people. However, that was established in his "I like to kill them softly" monologue, so (great as Gandolfini is) Mickey is a frivolous character.

There are things to appreciate about Killing Them Softly but the stylish scenes of mayhem would be much more powerful with a stronger film surrounding them. It is imperfect, but I can't escape the feeling that a better film exists in there somewhere. Because it aspires to be more than a simple crime thriller there will be those who hail it as a masterpiece, but I'm unable to ignore its shortcomings. I know there's a fine film within Killing Them Softly, this just isn't it.

"Killing Them Softly" may have big time actors like James Gandolfini, Ray Liotta and Brad Pitt, but the movie is as small as any other independent low budget film you may venture to see. Its premise centers around a culture of despair and desperation that has gripped our country. There is no musical soundtrack in the film. The tone of the film is captured with sound bites and clips of President's Barack Obama and George Bush, talking about hope and unity, all the while our country is falling farther and farther into economic ruin. With that ruin comes a new era of gangster, mob, crime mentality. With that ruin comes characters like Frankie and Russell, who are desperate enough to pull off a robbery just for a paycheck.

Jackie Cogan is called in by a secret group of men who want to know who robbed their card game of $100,000 and want somebody to pay. Pitt pulls off Cogan's menacing charm with ease. He has to be somebody who is capable of awful things, but could easily friend you at the drop of a hat. Gandolfini is a fellow hit man who comes in because one of the jobs Cogan is asked to do is of a personal nature. While his character is interesting, his relevance becomes questionable and the two long talky scenes that he is in become even more troublesome.

"Killing Them Softly" is 100% independent film. It has a gangster movie type feel to it, but character exploration is at its heart. The scenes are real and effective. Although there are too many long scenes, most notably the scenes with Gandolfini that serve little to no purpose and weigh the film down. Yet, as I stated earlier, the Presidential sound bites that loom over the film are effective and add validity to a movie that probably wouldn't have been as good without them. When desperation becomes more prevalent and the people in charge are full of hot air, things and people happen. Despair is a very real thing and we have all become reliant upon paychecks and money. The events of the film unfold, but the true message of the film last long afterward.

Watching Killing Them Softly was like my first attempt to read George Higgins Cogan's Trade. I picked up the book because of Andrew Dominick's involvement with a film adaptation and was a huge plus after Chopper and The Assassination of Jesse James. Cogan's Trade to say the least was an eye opening experience something that took me two tries to get the hang of Higgins use of dialogue using conversations to push plot over prose. In fact of the two books I've read his dialogue is more immersive than his descriptions of action. Higgins wasn't overburdening his novels with too much twists or overly complicated plot. Reading that much dialogue crammed into pages was dizzying to say the least something that translates to the film. There's not much action instead focusing on conversations of the characters instead. Higgins wasn't so much writing novels as plays in a way.
In fact Cogan's Trade and Killing Them Softly both have a rather simple plot, something that fits with the original title that was unfortunately changed months before release. After a mob backed card game is held up by two punks working for an intermediate, the mob contacts hitman Jackie Cogan to put things right and get the card games back up and running. What procedes are a lot of conversations between Jackie, thiefs Frankie and Russel, and Mickey a killer flown in to kill a man who knows Cogan's reputation as a killer. Adapted from the book its all basically following the business of Cogan's Trade adorned with with a rather overbearing need to tie Cogan's killings with that of the current economic issues of 2008 when the film takes place.
Other than the overkill with the films point one of the main problems of the film is it doesn't do much with the material which makes the characters suffer outside of Cogan who for those who enter the film cold comes across as ruthless but economical in how he handles his job. Frankie is too much of a simpering twit who Scoot Mcnairy does what He can with the character. Ben Mendhelson does a better job with the comic relief of strung out Russel and Ray Liotta adds some sympathy as Markie the gangster who has to be killed simply for his past transgressions.
Dominik hasn't really changed much from the book. Every scene of the movie is mainly unchanged every conversation verbatim only adding a bit of cynicism with a conversation between Jenkins and Pitt at the finale. The financial crisis takes center stage too much so with every radio and television blaring news and talk radio in an effort that makes the political billboard at the start of the movie seem tame by comparison. Its overdone which makes another decision seem strange in changing the setting from Higgins Boston to New Orleans. Unlike the news which gives you a feel of time setting the film in New Orleans doesn't really work out for much as if you're not from the city you might really not notice much and the film doesn't do much with it making the change seem strange over pointed.
What Dominik doesn't do with writing at least his direction is top notch in creating a grim and beautiful scneario. Theres humor that wasn't really in the book but scenes like a beating in a rain storm or a slowmotion execution are highlights for the films visual flair. The main holdup is exemplary in its suspense and the meetings between Jenkins and Pitt follow the main point of Higgins novel in making the act of killing come across as a business.
The movie is a film that doesn't work well. Higgins novel that reads like a play works better in the intimate way reading a book can as Dominik doesn't really do much with the material outside of simple straight adaptation. Killing Them Softly is a soft misfire for a good director.

Johnny Amato (Vincent Curatola) runs a dry cleaning business and is a low level crime entrepreneur. He hires two guys to rob a poker game filled with organized criminals. Frankie (Scoot McNairy) is the lead robber, a man who is a Steve Buscemi type. He has help from an unkempt Australian junkie friend named Russell (Ben Mendelsohn), who walks pets for a living. He hopes to be a drug dealer to change his life.

The reason why they believe they can get away with the job is because Markie Trattman (Ray Liotta) had done this job once before. He will surely be blamed. After the job is pulled, hitman Jackie (Brad Pitt) is brought in to sort things out and make things right. Jackie is thoughtful, soft spoken, and cynical. Since he knows Johnny, he hires Mickey (James Gandolfini) to do the job, a man who has multiple issues.

There are a number of things which set this film apart from other crime movies. First is the dialouge. It is clear the people are uneducated, except for Jackie who speaks as if he lives in two worlds. The ignorance of the robbers is brought to light when they wear bright yellow cleaning gloves to perform their task.

The second aspect is the background sound on both the radio, TV, and jukeboxes. It is the macrocosm of what is happening on the screen, and sometimes in an ironic fashion. The time period is the 2008 election season during the financial collapse. We hear "restore confidence in the financial system" and "it's all too familiar" on the radio when Markie is about to take the fall. Every time "B" actor Ray Liotta got punched or kicked, I would think, This is for "Entitled" or This is for "Ticket Out." Here is one for "The Son of No One."

The symbolism of the background announcements is brought to light at the end, in case you failed to catch it in the opening scene. A smart film for people who enjoy crime dramas.

Parental Guide: F-bombs, no sex, no nudity. Blood splatter, killing, beatings.
